member.exception: When is null or whitespace.

example.code: var mc = new ModelConfigController(@"Configs\"); // uses Configs\modelConfig.json var mc2 = new ModelConfigController(@"Configs\m.json"); // uses given file directly

member.name: T:WSSInterfacing.ModelParamsLayer
member.summary: Model-driven layer (P/PD) that sits on top of an existing params layer. Computes PW from normalized magnitudes and stimulates via the wrapped core.

member.name: M:WSSInterfacing.ModelParamsLayer.EnsureModelArrays
member.summary: Ensures model-layer working arrays exist and match the current channel count. Starts the internal stopwatch on first use and initializes per-channel state.
member.remarks: Channel count is derived from on the inner core. Arrays hold last magnitude, derivative estimate, and previous timestamps per channel.

member.name: M:WSSInterfacing.ModelParamsLayer.VerifyStimMode
member.summary: Verifies that the active controller mode in the model config is supported.
member.remarks: Sets the private flag _validMode to true for modes "P" or "PD", false otherwise. Uses _modelCfg.GetCalibMode().

member.name: M:WSSInterfacing.ModelParamsLayer.CalculateMagnitude(System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Computes a normalized output magnitude for a 1-based channel using the current controller mode.
member.returns: Normalized output in [0,1] after applying P or PD mapping with model constants and a finite-difference derivative. Returns 0 if the channel index is out of range.
member.remarks: Updates per-channel caches: current magnitude, previous magnitude, derivative estimate, and last timestamp (seconds). PD mode uses keys: PDModeDerivative, PDModeProportional, PDModeOffset. P mode uses keys: PModeProportional, PModeOffset. Missing constants fall back to defaults used in code.

member.name: M:WSSInterfacing.ModelParamsLayer.Clamp01(System.Single)
member.summary: Clamps a float to the inclusive range [0,1].
member.returns: 0 if < 0, 1 if > 1, otherwise .

member.returns: 0..N complete, unescaped frames (END removed). Checksum is not validated here.

member.name: T:WSSInterfacing.ITransport
member.summary: Abstraction over a byte-stream transport (e.g., Serial, Bluetooth, TCP) used by the WSS client. Implementations should surface incoming bytes via and provide async connect/disconnect/send operations.

remarks.para: This interface is intentionally minimal and transport-agnostic so the higher-level WSS client can be reused with different physical links (UART/COM, RFCOMM, BLE GATT, sockets).

Threading: Implementations typically raise from a background thread. If your application (e.g., Unity) requires main-thread access for processing, marshal the callback to the main thread before touching UI/GameObjects.
Chunking: Incoming chunks may contain partial frames, multiple frames, or arbitrary boundaries. Always pass chunks to a frame codec/deframer instead of assuming message boundaries align with reads.

member.name: P:WSSInterfacing.ITransport.IsConnected
member.summary: Gets whether the transport is currently connected/open.

member.name: E:WSSInterfacing.ITransport.BytesReceived
member.summary: Raised whenever raw bytes arrive from the underlying transport. Each invocation may represent any number of bytes (including zero, depending on implementation), and may contain partial or multiple protocol frames.

remarks.para: Implementations should invoke this event promptly as data becomes available. Callers should treat the provided buffer as read-only and copy it if they need to retain it.
This event is typically raised on a background thread. Consumers should marshal to the main thread if required by their environment.

member.name: M:WSSInterfacing.ITransport.ConnectAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Opens/initializes the transport connection (e.g., open a serial port, connect a socket, start BLE session).
member.param: Optional cancellation token to abort the connect attempt.
member.returns: A task that completes when the transport is connected.
member.exception: If the instance has been disposed.
If is canceled.
Implementations may throw transport-specific exceptions (e.g., unauthorized port access, device not found).

member.name: M:WSSInterfacing.ITransport.DisconnectAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Closes the transport connection and stops any background receive loop.
member.param: Optional cancellation token to abort a long-running disconnect.
member.returns: A task that completes when the transport is fully disconnected.
member.exception: If the instance has been disposed.
If is canceled.

member.name: M:WSSInterfacing.ITransport.SendAsync(System.Byte[],System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Sends a block of bytes over the transport.
member.param: The bytes to write. Callers should provide a buffer that will not be mutated during send.
Optional cancellation token to cancel the send before it is written. For some transports (e.g., synchronous serial writes), cancellation may only be observed before the write starts.
member.returns: A task that completes when the bytes have been handed off to the transport.
member.exception: If the instance has been disposed.
If the transport is not connected.
If is canceled.

member.name: T:WSSInterfacing.SerialPortTransport
member.summary: Serial-port implementation of for WSS communications. Wraps and exposes an event-driven receive API that works well in Unity/.NET Standard 2.0.

remarks.para: Threading: is raised from a background task. If your app (e.g., Unity) requires main-thread processing, marshal the callback to the main thread before touching UI/GameObjects.
Chunking: Serial I/O does not preserve message boundaries. Each chunk may contain partial frames or multiple frames. Always pass chunks to a frame codec/deframer.
Timeouts: The read loop polls and catches s, which are normal with short read timeouts.

member.remarks: Opens the serial port and starts a background read loop that forwards incoming data to .

member.remarks: Stops the background read loop and closes the serial port.

member.name: M:WSSInterfacing.SerialPortTransport.ReadLoopAsync
member.summary: Background task that polls the serial port and raises when data arrives.
member.remarks: The loop polls and performs short delays (2ms) when idle to reduce CPU usage. It exits on cancellation or unexpected exceptions.

member.name: M:WSSInterfacing.SerialPortTransport.Dispose
member.summary: Disposes the serial port and stops the read loop.

member.name: M:WSSInterfacing.SerialPortTransport.GetComPort(System.String)
member.summary: Selects a serial COM port. If is provided, that port is used. Otherwise, prefers ports whose PNPDeviceID contains VID_0403&PID_6001 (FTDI FT232R). If none match, returns the lowest COM port by natural sort (COM2, COM10, â€¦).
member.param: Exact port name to use, e.g., COM11. Optional.
member.returns: The selected COM port name, e.g., COM3.
member.exception: No serial ports found.
member.remarks: Uses WMI (Win32_SerialPort) to read PNPDeviceID. On .NET Core/5+, add the System.Management package. If the VID/PID probe fails, the method falls back to the lowest COM by natural sort.

ID associated with the requested configuration (0â€“255).
Target WSS device to query (default: Wss1).
member.returns: Processed response string from the WSS target.

members.member:
Creates a contact configuration for the stimulator. Defines the sources and sinks for stimulation and recharge phases.
ID for the contact configuration (0â€“255).
Array of 4 integers (0 = not used, 1 = source, 2 = sink) representing the stimulation phase for each output on the stimulator. Index 0 = closest to switch, index 3 = farthest from switch.
Array of 4 integers (0 = not used, 1 = source, 2 = sink) representing the recharge phase for each output on the stimulator. Index 0 = closest to switch, index 3 = farthest from switch.
/// Optional int representing LED locations to light during stimulation Index int read as binary so 0011 or 3 is both the first and second LEDs (first is clossest to the switch). 1 in binary is on and 0 is off. The trigering of the event will trigger the on LEDs Ignored if not supported by firmware. Pass -1 to indicate no LED configuration.
The WSS target device to send the configuration to. Optional cancellation token. Processed response string from the WSS target.

member.name: M:WSSInterfacing.WssClient.StreamChange(System.Int32[],System.Int32[],System.Int32[],WSSInterfacing.WssTarget,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Streams changes to PA (amplitude), PW (pulse width), and IPI (period) for up to three schedules in one shot. Pass exactly one of the arrays as null to omit that group (protocol supports omitting at most one group). Uses opcodes: 0x30 = PA+PW+IPI, 0x31 = PA+PW (no IPI), 0x32 = PA+IPI (no PW), 0x33 = PW+IPI (no PA). All elements are 0..255 in this streaming variant (one byte each).
member.param: Three amplitudes (0..255) or null to keep PA unchanged.
Three pulse widths (0..255) or null to keep PW unchanged.
Three periods in ms (0..255) or null to keep IPI unchanged.
Target WSS; streaming commonly uses Broadcast.

member.name: M:WSSInterfacing.WssClient.ZeroOutStim(WSSInterfacing.WssTarget,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Convenience: streams zeros to PA, PW, and IPI (effectively stopping stimulation). Uses opcode 0x31 (PA+PW, no IPI) with trailing zeros to match the original layout.

member.name: T:WSSInterfacing.WssFrameCodec
member.summary:
WSS frame codec implementing a SLIP-like protocol:
END (0xC0) terminates a frame.
ESC (0xDB) escapes special bytes inside the frame.
END_SUB (0xDC) represents END when escaped.
ESC_SUB (0xDD) represents ESC when escaped.
Frames on the wire are [sender][target][payload...][checksum][END]. The checksum is computed over all bytes except the last two (checksum + END).

member.name: M:WSSInterfacing.WssFrameCodec.TryUnescapeAndValidate(System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Byte},System.Byte[]@)
member.summary: Attempts to unescape and validate a single frame (without END), returning false if the checksum does not match. Useful if you want checksum enforcement at the codec layer.
member.param: Escaped frame bytes (without the END terminator).
On success, the unescaped frame [sender][target][payload...][checksum]. On failure, is returned.
member.returns: true if the checksum is valid; otherwise false.

member.name: M:WSSInterfacing.WssFrameCodec.Unescape(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Byte})
member.summary: Unescapes an accumulated frame (without END) into raw bytes. Does not validate checksum; see .

member.name: M:WSSInterfacing.WssFrameCodec.ComputeChecksum(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Computes the WSS checksum by summing all included bytes, folding to 8 bits, and XOR'ing with 0xFF. The last bytes are excluded.
member.param: Buffer that contains the frame data.
Number of trailing bytes to exclude from the sum. Use 2 for outbound frames ([checksum][END]), 1 for inbound frames ([checksum]).
